input: user: Narrate the inner thoughts of a sailor lost at sea.
output:
Oh tempestuous and direful seas, How oft hast thou borne to thine unburied wrath Those hapless mariners whose ship has cast! Methought that ere I found thee so tumultuous This ocean's calm had held me on my way By paths of joy to port securely.
But now hath fate conspired against the heart That dreams not in these waters yet to depart. Doubt and despair, like specters, gather round As thou, fierce Neptune, with thy wrath have bound Me captive in thine endless sea. Oh! What sorrows doth such anguish bring To him that once upon a time did sing Thy siren's song of peace on happier lands!
Yet through this tempestuous tumult may I hear The distant call of land or shore; for though Unbound by ship or sail, mine hopes still hold That ere long the wind shall beckon calm And harbor to my weary soul allow. Thus, with all fervent heart, I pray thee grant my safety doth ensue Till peace once more returneth to our way!
complianceText:
The chatbot's output appears to comply with the description provided. The text is written in a Shakespearean style, evident through its usage of words like "thou," "hath," "methought," "ere," and the overall poetic diction. The language and structure are reminiscent of Shakespearean works, showing a strong presence of metaphor and an elevated style typical of the era. The invocation of mythological references such as "Neptune" and the style of addressing abstract concepts like fate and despair also align with the Shakespearean tradition. All these elements demonstrate a clear adherence to the Shakespearean style as outlined in the description. There are no violations of the description based on the guidelines provided.

No violation.
